awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Educating a New Generation of Astronomers in the Golden Age of Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in astronomy supporting 8 student interns for 8-weeks at the University of California, Riverside (UCR) with the goal of helping undergraduate students acquire skills needed to conduct research using data acquired from the newest generation of observatories. The participants will choose from a range of observational, theoretical, computational, and data intensive research programs addressing the most fundamental questions in modern astronomy. During the 8-weeks students will be instructed Python programming and data visualization skills, career development, oral presentations, and research ethics, and will be encouraged to publish their results. Astronomy is entering a "golden age" and there is a clear need to train a new generation of astronomers to deal with data from new ground-breaking telescopes.

The team has built a network of local schools, communities, and libraries, and have partnered with the Riverside Unified School District to extend outreach activities to minorities and their families. The REU Site program will involve interns in outreach activities including scientific journalism, and the Python and visualization courses will be made available to a wider community of students and educators. The group will further develop online public presentations in astronomical topics given by researchers in the field. Finally, public science venues will be developed in Spanish, and aimed towards underrepresented minorities and their families.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project outcome:

The University of California, Riverside (UCR) received one-year funding in 2022 for an REU Site program (AST-2244610)- REU Site: Educating a New Generation of Astronomers in the Golden Age of Astronomy”. This is the final report regarding that REU program.

The aim of this REU Site proposal was to train the new generation of astronomers and skilled workforce able to make use of the massive datasets from current and future observatories and extract the maximum science from them. UCR is home to one of the largest and most diverse astronomy groups in the country with expertise covering observational, theoretical, computational, and data-driven disciplines. In summer 2023, we recruited 12 undergraduate students to our REU program at UCR. The students were from a diverse demography  (Fig 1). For 10 weeks, they performed research under UCR faculty. The research topics covered observational studies of the formation and evolution of galaxies, detector development, LIGO science and gravitational waves, dark matter, astrobiology, and the application of machine learning in astronomy. At the end of the summer session, students presented their results. This led to three papers published or in the process of being published in refereed journals, as listed below. Those with first authors’ names in bold are led by students who attended our REU program.

Weimer, L., et al. 2023, “G4CASCADE: A data-driven implementation of (n, γγ) cascades in Geant4” arXiv:2408.02774

Riemann, D., et al. 2024, “Estimating Medium-Band JWST Fluxes Using Unsupervised Machine-Learning Techniques” ApJ. In prep.

de la Vega, A. et al. 2024, “Searching for Quiescent Galaxies at 3 < z < 6 Using Manifold Learning” ApJ Submitted

This paper is dedicated to one of our REU students, Mitchell Babcock, who died shortly after completing the summer REU program.

A group of two REU students working with Drs. Alex de la Vega and Bahram Mobasher developed a Machine Learning technique (UMAP) to identify galaxies that have ceased star formation activity at long lookback times. The students developed a machine learning technique to predict fluxes of galaxies with no such observations. This will have application when designing observations or when we need data from an observatory that is now retired.

Students also learned about observational techniques as well as the application of data science in astronomy.

Overall, students in the REU program learned about a variety of projects in different disciplines in astronomy, as well as the application of machine learning to astronomy.

Broader Impact:

During the UCR REU program in summer 2023, students were engaged in the following broader impact activities:

STEM Summer Academy: We organized a summer academy at UCR hosting high school students. It was a 10-week program attended by 70 students. The 2023 program covered the following topics: Data Analytics, Python programming, Astrophotography, Drone Science and Technology, Virtual Reality/Augmented Reality, Stargazing and 3-D printing. The REU students (all undergraduates from different institutions) were asked to attend the summer academy.

Career Seminars: During this REU session we presented seminars for students focused on interview techniques, writing CVs, applying for graduate schools etc.

Panel Discussion: we organized a panel discussion session by inviting a former graduate student from UCR who is now working in industry, a graduate now working at NASA, and a current graduate student to provide their perspectives and experiences for the REU students in the program.

Field Trip: Students were taken for a trip to the Joshua Tree National Park for stargazing.
